articles.headline: A Milk Giant Goes Broke as Americans Reject Old Staples
articles.snippet: Dean Foods filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday. It’s not the first food giant to be caught off guard by a shift in tastes.
articles.abstract: Dean Foods filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday. It’s not the first food giant to be caught off guard by a shift in tastes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Samuel E. Dean Sr. founded his milk company at a processing facility in Illinois, milkmen still delivered pints to homes all over the United States and children dutifully drank three glasses a day.

articles.headline: News or ‘Trauma Porn’? Student Journalists Face Blowback on Campus
articles.snippet: Incidents at Northwestern and Harvard reveal a growing tension between traditional journalistic practices and the demands of student activists.
articles.abstract: Incidents at Northwestern and Harvard reveal a growing tension between traditional journalistic practices and the demands of student activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Jeff Sessions, President Trump’s former attorney general, was speaking to a packed lecture hall on Northwestern University’s campus last week, but the real action was unfolding offstage.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith and Kate Taylor

articles.headline: Impeachment Hearings Open With Revelation on Trump’s Ukraine Pressure
articles.snippet: As public hearings began, William B. Taylor Jr., the top American diplomat in Ukraine, said he was told President Trump cared more about investigating Joe Biden than he did about Ukraine.
articles.abstract: As public hearings began, William B. Taylor Jr., the top American diplomat in Ukraine, said he was told President Trump cared more about investigating Joe Biden than he did about Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives opened historic impeachment hearings on Wednesday and took startling new testimony from a senior American diplomat that further implicated President Trump in a campaign to pressure Ukraine to publicly commit to investigating former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: WeWork Lost $1.25 Billion in Third Quarter
articles.snippet: The co-working company’s losses increased sharply as it expanded ahead of a failed initial public offering.
articles.abstract: The co-working company’s losses increased sharply as it expanded ahead of a failed initial public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rapid expansion of WeWork’s office-space empire caused the company’s losses to more than double in the third quarter, according to a company presentation.

articles.headline: On Capitol Hill, Old-School Washington Keeps Circus at Bay
articles.snippet: Seriousness itself stood trial as two diplomats, in defiance of the White House, testified on the first day of an impeachment spectacle.
articles.abstract: Seriousness itself stood trial as two diplomats, in defiance of the White House, testified on the first day of an impeachment spectacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After so much noise, a formal feeling fell upon the Capitol. The civil servants had entered the room.

articles.headline: Behind a Star Witness, Democrats Take Their Impeachment Case to the Public
articles.snippet: Their goal is to transform what might seem like an abstract debate over foreign policy into high crimes and misdemeanors in the public mind as Republicans argue there is no case for impeachment.
articles.abstract: Their goal is to transform what might seem like an abstract debate over foreign policy into high crimes and misdemeanors in the public mind as Republicans argue there is no case for impeachment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — William B. Taylor Jr. was the witness that Democrats had hoped Robert S. Mueller III would be but was not — the image, at least, of a wise, fatherly figure with Kevlar credibility expressing restrained but unmistakable disapproval of what he found when he turned over the rock.

articles.headline: ‘Baby Shark’ Smells Money Onstage
articles.snippet: After nearly 4 billion streams — and surprisingly little revenue — the viral predator is going on tour.
articles.abstract: After nearly 4 billion streams — and surprisingly little revenue — the viral predator is going on tour.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time the confetti cannons burst, the toddlers were shouting in ecstasy, their eyes fixed on the superstars onstage. Ten costumed performers were delivering the climax of “Baby Shark Live!” — a 75-minute adaptation of a two-minute music video, and an edge case in translating viral popularity into an enduringly profitable real-world franchise.

articles.headline: Deval Patrick Makes a Late Bid in the 2020 Presidential Campaign
articles.snippet: Mr. Patrick, the former Massachusetts governor, entered the Democratic primary with less than three months to go before the Iowa caucuses.
articles.abstract: Mr. Patrick, the former Massachusetts governor, entered the Democratic primary with less than three months to go before the Iowa caucuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — There is almost no campaign staff or ground operation. Some volunteers mobilized on one day’s notice. The announcement video was not finished until the middle of the night, and an email with instructions for Day 1 was sent to a small inner circle at 2:48 a.m.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon, Jonathan Martin and Matt Stevens

articles.headline: Highways on Fire. Semesters Cut Short. A Recession. Can Hong Kong Heal?
articles.snippet: Months of antigovernment protests and increasingly violent clashes with the police have upended daily life, with the potential to alter the city’s character.
articles.abstract: Months of antigovernment protests and increasingly violent clashes with the police have upended daily life, with the potential to alter the city’s character.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Storefronts closed for weekend demonstrations are now shuttered, for weeks or even permanently. Protesters are occupying major roads, rail tracks, bridges and tunnels, cutting off critical thoroughfares for commuters and commerce on a daily basis. Universities are telling students not to come back for the rest of the semester.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Edward Wong and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Smith & Wesson’s Owner to Break Away From Gun Business
articles.snippet: The move separates the broader company from the challenges the gun industry faces. It was announced shortly before another mass shooting.
articles.abstract: The move separates the broader company from the challenges the gun industry faces. It was announced shortly before another mass shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gun-maker Smith & Wesson was once an iconic national brand, a symbol of Americana and rugged individualism dating back to the battlefields of the Civil War.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Apple’s Reach Reshapes Medical Research
articles.snippet: The company’s tools enable researchers to track huge numbers of people. But doctors do not yet know if it will significantly improve health outcomes.
articles.abstract: The company’s tools enable researchers to track huge numbers of people. But doctors do not yet know if it will significantly improve health outcomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1976, the Harvard School of Public Health and two other major medical institutions started a study on nurses that has become one of the largest and longest research efforts ever conducted on women’s health. They have so far enrolled more than 275,000 participants.
